I wouldn’t pay the full price but on sale this is a decent walking simulator if you enjoy the genre

author: {'steamid': '76561198046357751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1633454336}
review:
Totally not for VR. 
No motion controller support, you have to teleport everywhere, or walk by making ONE step per button pressed (?!) 
No ability to interact with objects manually. If you want to open the door, you can’t take the handle and open it, you have to point at the door with the laser and press a button. If you want to take an object you need to, again, point at it, press the button, then it hovers above your controller and then disappears in your chest somewhere. You can’t actually “take” or “hold” anything.
The game itself is good, story is pretty engaging, but I expected more VR-oriented gameplay since, well… it supports it at all. This is the first time I see something like that in a VR game, and that was an unpleasant surprise. So unpleasant that I actually wanted to refund it, but decided to keep it for the story. I mean, no controller motion? No taking anything in your hand? Why bother making it VR at all, if even these things are not there? It simply kills the immersion completely, what's the point then? Like come on, even small and cheap games like Ok, Bob has direct object interaction! 
So, if you are planning to play this in VR, my advise here is don’t. The experience will be annoying and disappointing. 
Non VR users - wait till the sales and go for it, it’s not brilliant, but still pretty good.

review:
(Vive) Начну с разочарования. Как же скучно. Как часто бывает в "историях" - куча монологов, записок, аудиозаписок, замечаний от первого лица по поводу каждого найденного предмета и просто мыслей вслух. Куча незнакомых людей с именами и фамилиями обращаются друг к другу то по имени, то по фамилии и пишут друг другу кучу писем. И их надо читать, там же коды и подсказки. Надоедает от игры к игре. На моей памяти только в The Station история, поданная таким образом, захватила, люди там казались реально живыми.
Также контроллы. Работают вроде нормально, но назначены, как-то странновато. Движение и взаимодействие оба на триггер, в зависимости от контекста, и попробуй отойди от мусорки, а не щелкай крышкой.
Тем не менее, игра большая, проработанная, многодетальная, красиво и тщательно сделана. Там есть движущиеся люди, и они тоже хорошо выглядят. Если не торопишься, можно вникать и размышлять.
*** Хорошо что доиграла сама и заглянула в дискуссии. Несколько концовок, интерес вернулся, ура!

review:
I give up. I really wanted to like this game, but the autosave system is worthless. It saves once per chapter... which if you're a completionist like me, might take you 20 minutes. So, combine a save once every twenty minutes with a buggy game that can't tolerate losing your headset and you're going to find yourself repeating entire levels... A LOT.  it's happened to me no less than 4 or 5 times. 

Almost to the end of a level and I accidentally teleport into a wall... game freezes.... crashes... and I'm back at the start of the chapter.

My Vive wireless battery goes dead... normally not a big deal with most games. Pop on a new battery and your back in business with most games pausing and letting you jump right back in. Not this one, you lose your audio, completely... no way to recover without restarting the game. 15 minutes into a level and I'm left with no audio or way to load a recent save.

It's not like the game is all that challenging.... why isn't there a more frequent save system? Maybe save with every collectible I pick up? Save with each minor accomplishment within a chapter. Or, sin of all sins, let me save my progress on demand.

review: First off as a heads up, I am playing this game using an Oculus Quest headset running Oculus Link on my PC. All PC specs meet or exceed requirements for VR. I wanted to play this game using VR so I did not try it out in non-VR, although it appears that it would be more enjoyable in playing without VR. I'm looking for titles that will allow me to justify my VR purchase so that it will get used and not just become a novelty gathering dust in a closet. I am a longtime player of graphics type adventures games, (Former Sierra On-Line employee). I purchased this game as the premise looked very promising. Unfortunately, movement in the game is very slow and navigating around in the environment is cumbersome at best. Also, the lack of instructions in respects to moving around in the game doesn't help. What it takes 5 minutes to accomplish in VR could easily be done in 30 seconds in non-VR using a mouse/keyboard. Game play in VR should be easier and more intuitive than using a mouse and keyboard, such as it is with games like Vader Immortal. Examples of issues I encountered: when you are playing as Pearson and the game suggests that you answer the phone, I spent 10 minutes trying to find the phone finally realizing there was no handset. Answering the phone shouldn't be a puzzle.  The next issue I encountered was in trying to put the sample under the microscope, I retrieved it from the fridge, but somehow dropped it and it disappeared, which means you can't complete the next step. The vial should have either shown up on the floor where it could be picked back up or reappeared back in the fridge. It is a great effort on the part of the company and maybe I'll try it again at a later date when I have more experience with VR, but as of right now it 's too slow and cumbersome to justify my time, (especially the time) and money. Refund requested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050672642', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1575411533}
review:
Amazing single player VR adventure. You play two characters that occasionally switch roles in a way that is not disturbing and keeps you focused but allows you to refresh your mind every so often. The puzzles are good, narrative excellent! And I really enjoyed the moral dilemmas.

The control scheme is a little unorthodox and the sound system sometimes allows you to hear sounds that you are far away from (like the newtonian balls in the ADAM room after you have left it). But these are just minor criticisms, I really enjoyed this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025309409', 'num_games_owned': 14496, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1572760627}
review:
"The Assembly" is a short first-person adventure with an interesting story, mild puzzles and moral dilemmas, crisp graphics, and excellent voice acting. It can be played in VR or as a regular non-VR game - this review is meant for the latter, as I do not have the equipment for the former.

The story contains two alternating plots that barely intersect, both focusing on "The Assembly", a secret group of brilliant maverick scientists who do self-funded research without governmental control or supervision. One plot revolves around a scientist who has been "invited" to join the group, but needs to solve trials to prove herself - these start with simple logical puzzles, and then turn into moral dilemmas to explore her personality. The second plot follows one of the scientists in The Assembly, who discovers that something is going dangerously wrong, collects evidence, and tries to flee and inform the authorities. Both plots touch on the ethics, chances, and risks of scientific research and progress. While neither goes very deep, these topics kept the game interesting and engaging for me. Some of your choices affect the ending of the game, and you can later revisit single chapters to make a different choice, see a different ending, or search for collectibles that you may have missed.

Many puzzles require a bit of thought and an eye for spotting relevant information in the environment, but they remain easy throughout the game. They succeeded in keeping me engaged without distracting from the story - this game is obviously intended to be immersive rather than challenging.

Graphics are crisp and fitting for a facility that mostly consists of various laboratories, offices, and a few living rooms. Sound effects are okay, though the game sometimes processes them in a weird way - start to play with a Newton's cradle in one room, and you can still here its clacking noise 50m away and through several walls. The voice acting stands out for its exceptional quality, the actors have interesting voices and deliver their lines very believably.

Unfortunately the game insists on WASD movement and does not feature key remapping. I wouldn't consider this a dealbreaker since you never need to move precisely or react quickly, you can get by with just using the forward key and the mouse. But it's definitely annoying that such a basic and for many players important QoL feature was overlooked.

I recommend the game to players who like story-driven adventure games without action elements, and who like to think about the risks and chances of science. However, the price seems a bit high for the amount of content it offers, especially if you have no use for the VR version. I'd suggest to get it on a sale.

review:
A fun, low-key, story-driven game that makes a good use of the VR medium. The pace is a little slow, but the world feels really big and immersive, the puzzles are fun, and the game pushes you to make some ethical judgments that had me a little teary-eyed in my headset. By the end, it's hard not to get sucked in. There are multiple endings, and you get to compare your choices and game stats against those made by other players. 

The one real con for me was that the controls (playing on the HTC Vive with controllers) were a little funky and hard to get the hang of whenever I hopped back into the game after a long break, but I wouldn't say this was a big detractor from the game overall. If you're looking for a good story-driven VR game, this is worth a look.

review:
I'm honestly kinda on the fence about this one. The description says "...a long-form game designed for VR" but the 'designed for VR' part doesn't always show.

For the most part, the objects in the games are proportioned correctly, so that's probably what a lot of the 'for VR' efforts went to (if you've ever played a 'flat' game with VR hacked in, a lot of times the scale of objects in the world is waaaaay off).

I'm under the impression this game was mostly developed before motion controls were 'a thing' - and that's why the motion controller support that was added is simply point-n-click (as in you point a laser point at a drawer, click, and the drawer slides open). 

Either way, it's a pretty looking game, and the story is alright so far (I'm near the end, but not quite done with it yet - I'll probably polish it off this afternoon, actually...)

author: {'steamid': '76561198066590240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2800, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1500778359}
review:
I wish Steam had a third option (neutral), instead of a yes or no recommendation.  I would recommend this game only on a deep sale (at around $5 or less).  I played and completed this game on the Oculus Rift on Steam in 5.7 hours with a lot of leaving the game playing in the background.

Pros:
Nice visuals
Easy puzzles/some are actually fun
Interesting concept
nice parts to the story
Very nice leaderboard at the end to compare yourself to other players (a very nice touch to this type of genre!)

Cons:
very tedious fetch gameplay (whether it's "discovering" passwords or finding a key)
some very boring puzzles
poor mechanics, poor POV in spots
teleporting everywhere
most of the story is drab, you have no reason to care for either of the characters you play, the AI is more interesting and it's got a very short narrative on the AI
your choices don't really matter
game crashed once, had to restart whole level, also had trouble starting on Oculus Rift (had to exit and come back to Steam for it to properly start)

Nuetral:
voice acting is okay
game ran smooth other than problems noted above
not too long or short
meh epilogue .. probably would have been better left to imagination
you can move forward but it's jagged (but at least the option is there, unlike other VR games!)

overall I would give it a 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198001813417', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 850, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1499333735}
review:
The Assembly von nDreams ist ein kurzes Adventure mit einer interessanten Erzählweise. Eine absolute Empfehlung!

The Assembly ist ein spannendes Adventure, ganz ohne physische Gewalt. Getragen von einer interessanten Geschichte, in der man in mehreren  Kapiteln zwischen zwei Protagonisten hin und her tauscht. Man interagiert mit Computern und es gibt diverse Puzzle zu lösen. Es sind mindestens zwei unterschiedliche Enden zu erspielen. Das Ende, dass ich bei meinem ersten Durchgang gesehen habe, könnte für mich nach einem zweiten Teil aussehen .... aber das sind sicherlich nur Wunschgedanken.

Es gibt bisher nicht viele Adventure-Spiele dieser Art im VR-Bereich, dass dieses dann auch noch komplett in deutscher Sprache spielbar ist macht es fast schon zu einem Pflichtkauf. Die deutschen Sprecher sind sehr gut ausgewählt und klingen professionel. Endlich mal ohne Untertitel spielen zu können ist schön, zumal Untertitel in VR immer etwas störend sind. 

Die Einführung in die Geschichte ist allerdings etwas irritierend. Der Spieler bekommt diese in der Egoperspektive erzählt und da der Protagonist dort in einem Rollstuhl sitzt, während man selbst steht, kann es vorkommen, dass man auch mal durch den Rolli durchläuft o.ä.
 
Die Grafik ist aber passend und man fühlt sich schnell im Geschehen. Es gibt leider ein Problem mit der Kolisionsabfrage von Wänden, dadurch ist es möglich durch Wände zu gucken, indem man seinen Kopf reinsteckt oder Roomscale ausnutzt. Allerdings kann man dadurch nur in andere Räume reinsehen, aber nicht mit Dingen dort interagieren. Das geht nur, wenn es auch "offiziel" Zutritt zu diesem Raum gibt.
 
 Die Steuerung ist o.k.. Leider gibt es keine Free Locomotion per Pad, nur Teleportation und ein etwas unnützes Blinken. Da könnte noch nachgebessert werden. Spielbar ist die Teleportsteuerung auf jeden Fall und irgendwann merkt man das nicht mehr so sehr. Zumal man sich in seinem Spielbereich ja bewegen kann.

 Die Interaktionen könnten natürlich, wie in jedem VR-Spiel, noch vielfältiger sein, aber das könnte dann auch nur von der Story ablenken. 
Vorsicht vor Mülleimern - ich bin des öfteren an diesen festgehangen - besonders, wenn sie neben Türen stehen.

Aber nichts desto trotz ein hervorragendes Spiel!

The Assembly by nDreams is a short adventure game with an interesting narrative style. An absolute recommendation!

The Assembly is a thrilling adventure game without any physical violence. Carried by an interesting story, in which you switch between two protagonists in several chapters. You interact with computers and there are several puzzles to solve. There are at least two different endings to play. The end I saw on my first run could look like a second part to me .... but that's surely just wishful thinking.

There are not many adventure games of this kind in the VR area, but the fact that this one is completely playable in German language makes it almost a must buy. The German speakers are very well selected and sound professional. Finally being able to play without subtitles is nice, especially since subtitles in VR are always a bit annoying. 

However, the introduction to the story is a bit irritating. The player is told the story in ego perspective and since the protagonist is sitting in a wheelchair while you are standing, it can happen that you walk through the wheelchair or similar.

Unfortunately there is a problem with the colliding detection of walls, so it is possible to look through walls by sticking your head inside or using roomscale. But you can only look into other rooms, but not interact with things there. This is only possible if there is "official" access to this room.
 
 The controls are ok. Unfortunately there is no Free Locomotion per pad, only teleportation and a somewhat useless flashing. This could be improved. The teleportation control is playable in any case and at some point you won't notice that much anymore. Especially since you can move around in your playing area.

 The interactions could of course be even more varied, as in any VR game, but that could then only distract from the story. 
Beware of trash cans - I often get stuck on them - especially when they are next to doors.

But nevertheless an excellent game!

If you like first-person exploration games with a slight touch of puzzles, this may be worthwhile when on sale. Otherwise, it'll probably feel lacking. It's not a Myst or Obduction or Talos or Quern. It's more like Firewatch, where there's not many puzzles and it's more about taking in the atmosphere and story than it is exploring worlds and solving puzzles. 

The game is essentially wandering around a few different floors of a secret research facility. There are a few puzzles, but not many, and they're not difficult either. Most of the gameplay is akin to wandering a floor, finding a key in a locker or a passcode on a computer, then using that to enter an area that was previously locked.

The game has an interesting theme but played more like an interactive story than a first-person puzzler.

author: {'steamid': '76561198197386775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1497311120}
review:
Using an HTC Vive.

With all of the wave shooters you see on the store for VR, I think this is a pretty great game. There aren't a lot of games that really capture me, but the storyline in this title was [i]interesting enough[/i] to keep playing. Yes it is pretty slow paced and not challenging, but at least it's a relaxing experience. The environments are very detailed and realistic. Graphics overall are superb. Audio is pretty realistic sounding too. I only have two negatives. One, the people are really short and child-like. I think this is supposed to be a seated experience but it feels wrong not standing up. It's funny because everything in the environment feels normal when standing so I think just the AI people are incorrectly porportioned. 

The biggest 'issue' with this game, and the reason I don't really play it, is because it doesn't run well on my computer. My rx480 isn't the most powerful card out there and is pretty low end for VR but this is one of the only titles I've had issues with. Very choppy experience, and I don't see anywhere to change graphics settings. Eventually I will upgrade the graphics card and this game will be one of the first I get back to playing.

I would recommend, and I would pay $30 for this title if you're playing in VR. Not sure if this game is worth it if you're playing on a standard computer screen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096412999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1519073368}
review:
2 Minute Video Review → https://youtu.be/rNA0PqGljDs

The Assembly is an adventure game with a modern day storyline.

You alternate between two different characters’ story paths: A research scientist who works at The Assembly, and an applicant who is being tested by The Assembly. You take turns playing each character as the plot thickens and their stories converge.

Throughout the game you’ll be engaging in puzzles, item hunting, and moral choices. I think this game was originally made for flatscreens and then later adapted for VR, because you use the motion controllers like laser pointers whenever interacting with objects. But I actually don’t mind that in this game, since you’ll be searching through a lot of cabinets and containers looking for items and clues, and the laser pointer control scheme helps speed that up.

This was one of the first VR adventure games I bought, and I have a real soft spot for it. The voice acting is exceptional, all of the character performances feel genuine and I feel involved in each of their stories. 

And even though the story exists in the world of scientific research, I could follow along with the plot and was able to understand everything that was going on.

I’ve played through this game 3 times, I find it a lot of fun, it’s one of my favorite adventure games. The first time I played this it took me almost 5 hours to beat. 

The regular price is $30, but it routinely goes on sale for $15.
If you like narrative adventure games then I highly recommend it. It’s a real hidden gem.

-Fully voice acting, really good job
-multiple endings based on choice

- The puzzles keep the game interesting and flesh out the levels
- movement system good for people prone to nausea

Cons:
-Puzzles are pretty simple, but hey, at least you dont have to exit vive to look up answers
-All of the human models are like 4 feet tall what was up with that?? They look like dolls from the proportion

review:
Schönes Adventure mit einer durchgehend spannenden Geschichte und vielen interessanten Situationen. Zwar ist die Story etwas klischeehaft und hat auch ihre Tiefpunkte, aber sie funktioniert für das Spiel. Die Steuerung ist manchmal etwas zickig und man hätte mehr daraus machen können, gerade in puncto Interaktivität. Aber wenn man sich einmal dran gewöhnt hat, geht auch das gut von der Hand. Die Rätsel sind nicht sonderlich schwer (einige sind sogar zu leicht), aber sie machen trotzdem Spaß. Grafisch ist das Spiel überwiegend sehr gut gemacht, die Details sind teilweise hervorragend und die deutsche Vertonung professionell.

The Assembly ist derzeit wohl eines der besten Spiele für VR, nicht zuletzt deshalb, weil es eine komplette Geschichte erzählt, die nicht nach 30 Minuten zuende ist.

review:
Well, this is an interesting one. It's one of the better narrative experiences I've had in VR, with excellent voice work and a story that raises some interesting ethical questions without descending into ham fisted moralising. 

It's a shame that the controls are flat out awful, with a point and click style interface that desn't feel designed for VR, and the worst teleportation system I have ever experienced. It's not enough to render the game unplayable, but it does make the better aspects of the game something of a chore to get through.

It's also pretty short. I finished it in around three hours, although it does have some alternate endings and I'm sure I missed a few little ancilliary stories and easter eggs along the way. I bought it on sale and I'm happy with it for what I paid, but I think the full price is a little on the steep side. 

But if you finished A Chair in a Room and The Gallery and are looking for something more at the narrative adventure end of the scale than horror, You could certainly do far worse than this. I'm hoping for a sequel that sorts those horrible controls, but for now, this is pretty good if you're willing to overlook the flaws.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970695975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1597826000}
review:
One of the most original games I've ever played, The Assembly is based on extremely mature themes, highbrow ideas and more than a touch of science fiction. It is one of a new breed of indie games which delph into more serious and adult topics which borders on philosophical, making gaming an infinitely more cerebral experience which feels so much less passive and far more intellectually engaging.

The Assembly sees the player take two roles - two characters whose paths are intertwined, both based in the Assembly, an elite and secretive research society where science appears to bypass ethical and moral boundaries, and whose funding seems to be infinite. New employees are kidnapped and have to pass tests before earning the lucrative position, and if they reject it, have their brain wiped of memory of the entire incident before being returned to the real world.

The player is one such, Madeleine Stone, and an existing employee, Caleb Pearson, whose destinies play a vital role in the future of the organisation.

The Assembly is primarily built for VR, but keyboard and mouse works perfectly even if the gameplay and interactivity levels are limited - it works seamlessly, and it really is more of a story with some puzzles and button pressing. It also looks pretty good for an indie game, employing the very solid UE4. And the voice acting? Best I've heard in a video game - the main two protagonists are beautifully voiced, and the supporting cast isn't bad either.

The plot isn't easy to digest; it is deliberately a bit more highbrow than most video games, and a bit of knowledge of science jargon will definitely help; this is a game for a specific audience - most Joe and Jane Punters will not get this, and that is no insult to their intelligence. But if you do grasp where the story is going it'll grip you endlessly, and you'll be captivated to the end.

It's not the longest game, weighing in at about 4 hours, and is a bit pricey for that length, but the sheer quality does compensate for this with essentially a level of production which verges on AAA.

It's not for everyone - with some psychology, science, philosophy, ethical and moral questions in there, but if these themes appeal to you this will be for you. 

Highly recommended.

review:
Good game with some interesting choices, shows the potential for VR adventures. 

I enjoyed the game, it wasn't perfect, but I love this style of gaming, and VR is especially suited to it. Bought this when the Vive controls were added, and I am glad I did, even if it is just to support more experiences like this one. 

The Game has an interesting story, and I enjoyed exploring the environments and solving some of the puzzles. It is a little short, and it is obvious that it wasn't made with roomscale VR in mind. For example you don't just pick things up, instead you point a laser pointer at them. And the game obviously expects you to be sitting.

Other than that though I would definitely recommend if you can get it on a sale. Voice acting is good, the story is well written, and some of the choices I had to make were really difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166306431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1480727089}
review:
I believe the rule is if you can't say anything nice,. say nothing,. So I will start with the good things about this game.  The graphics are great! really some of the best I've seen in VR yet.  The Voice acting is really good and the sound is great.  

So now with the problems I have with this game.  First off it's painfully ovbvious it is a port into VR from your standard point and click computer adventure game.  When I'm playing VR I want to feel like I'm really there.  I want to be able to pick up and manipulate everything, like  in the Gallery, or SVRVIE or Chair in a room.   It really takes away from the immersion when you can only kind of interact with items that are highlighted with certian icons when your pointer from your motion controller passes over it.  

Speaking of Motion controllers.  the locomotion system is terrible.  I cannot tell you how many times I would teleport into the middle of a wall.  It feels like the developers were like, "Dang, we put all this time into this game and no one likes the locomotion so lets through in a quick teleport patch and not test it out to appease the masses."  Also they don't work well with the puzzles.  

Speaking of puzzles or game play,.. you spend your time in this game as two different characters.  The male characters game play, which is the bulk of the game, consists of opening drawers and lockers, reading emails and answering phones.  seriously,.. that's pretty much it.  the voice overs tell you everythiing you need to do and it's linear as hell and just boring.  I do all of those things every day at work.  The female's part of the game is a series of "puzzles" you need to solve.  One in particular involves moving these large floating cubes around with this joy stick,. only you don't actually grab the joy stick,.. you are supposed to use your thumb pad which is maddening because no matter which controller I used trying to get the cubes to move to the right was down right impossible.  or trying to move a highlighted number to the right on a key pad.  Did I mention the controls were just terrible in this game.  There was one puzzle where you had to walk around and solve this who done it type of murder mystery by listening to tapes opening drawers and reading emails... Ok now that I think about it it wasn't that great either. 

The story was also just boring as hell.  a bit preachy at times.   There is just no way that this game is worth 30 bucks.  I bought it when it was on sale for a pretty substantial amount after they "fixed" the control and locomotion issues.  seriously  maybe 5 bucks,.. there are just so many other games out there that are miles above this one.  pretty graphics just don't cut it when virtually everything else in the game sucks.

OK I didn't really go into the reasons I found this story so terrible for the whole spoiler factor for any one that didn't heed my warning and want to play this game any way so if you are reading and don't want the whole thing spoiled stop reading now.  

First off,. aftter 8 years of med school and 20 years of private practice this story certainly did not go over my head.  It was just that the whole "evil greedy corporation bioenginering pathogens to spread to an unsuspecting population through natural vectors like birds, monkeis, bugs, zombies, you name it"  has be done to death and if you are going to use that narrative at least make it interesting.   there were never any consequences for this and all you did was walk around and dig through file cabinets and read emails.  there was no suspence, no action, you would think that at least the security cameras that followed you around would alert the higher ups that you were up to something,.. messing with there "amazing" artificially intellegent main frame and all.  but no big deal there.   Carry on.  

Second,. What the hell was up with  those terrible, simplistic puzzles?  I mean really.  If this deep cover operation that employs only ninjas,.. (ok maybe they were some kind of filtration mask,. that eveyone wore every where,. or maybe a cheap way to not have to animate mouths) really wants to test their applicants to see how smart they are,. why woud they give them a bunch of easy grade school level test to perform?  And another thing,. why for the ever loving fuck, did this corporation build these GIANT freaking rooms do to test that could easily be done on a laptop?   That is just not a very good use of resources for your evil plans.  Speaking of giant stupid rooms,. the impossible outbreak puzzle??? really??  yeah that totally needed a big ass freatking room just so we could for some reason get a 30 year old argument about the dangers of irresponcible antibiotic use.  I totally see how that is relevant in this story.  

Third,. if you want to make me feel like there is some big moral choices to make at the end of the game, maybe they should have done a better job at getting me to know that character than "I experimented on my mom and my dad is a dick"  Take the money, exicute the old man, and why can't I just kill the baby now?

review:
I'm updating this review after ending the game. 6.2hrs with 22/29 achievements, I was quite sure to reach most of achievements to be honest, it's a good surprise (especially the achievement for collect all dossiers). Could be surely finished in the half of the time, if you jump away to dialogues or exploration, but with a such mood could be better an action game than an adventure.

Great story, extremely geek oriented, moral choices during the game and well... I'm sad the game is ended to be honest, not because it's short (to be a VR game it's quite long) but because I was totally involved into the story and honestly I hope in sequels or DLCs, so many side stories inside.

-----

Bought it after the handtracking support update, as I'm a Vive owner. What a game and what a graphics! It's basically a sort of point and click adventure, but for VR. The story seems extremely interesting, with good dialogues and voices, and english subtitles are activable if needed (please, consider to translate at least subtitles in many languages).

The roomscale use and the whole button assignment for Vive wands need some work, as the game was built over sitting + pad interface. But it's very easy to forgive this, with a such quality! Lots of interactive objects, pointing and activating instead grabbing like Job Simulator, but you can open any door or drawer.

Finally a real adventure for VR, and a good one.

About negative reviews until yesterday (quite a lot!) almost all of them came from Vive owners frustrated for the lack of handtracking. This is no more an issue.

review:
I have updated this review as the developer responded to the many requests for Vive controller support and has provided that.  As a result I re-bought the game and have enjoyed what I've played so far.  Full credit to the developers for listening to the Vive community and reacting.


My original review:
Returned this game for a refund as it didn't support my gamepad which works with all the other games I have.  Such a shame that a game that claims to be built for VR doesn't support the Vive controllers.  Should it ever do in the future I'll consider re-buying.  

I also consider the additional £5 for the VR unlock a bit of a slap in the face of the VR community.  If the game was primarily designed for VR but you are also looking to subsidise the development costs by selling into the 2D market place them why not reduce the cost to half way between the two and have one standard product that works on both.  VR players have already had to shell out a considerable amount on their hardware without having to pay a premium to unlock VR capability in a game that was designed to support it from the beginning!

I'm sure there is probably a decent game in there but In its current form I'm unable to recommend.

review:
I think that, as a Vive owner, I was a bit disappointed by the lack of motion controller support. I think when the Rift also has these, every game that involves walking about will absolutely *need* this capability - and I would guess The Assembly will get that in time. (If you want a good example of this, look to Vanishing Realms, a much lower visual fidelity game perhaps, but one that wins hugely in terms of immersion from its control method).

That said, plug in a 360 controller and it doesn't take long to become emersed in this title. It is clearly a big step up from much of the early bird stuff we've seen until now - an actual games studio producing a tentative step into the VR world. I still think it's only a first taste of what is possible, but at the very least a good first sip nonetheless.

UPDATE: Vive motion controllers are now supported, and - for me at least - this made a huge difference, moving around the game world is now so much better. Thanks to the devs, and well done!

review:
Ce jeu est en plusieurs épisodes ou quoi?? Ah ben non! Non sans rire essayons d'être constructifs.
Même si l'appréciation reste mitigée, je recommande vivement d'attendre une bonne promotion pour l'acheter. En bref:

Avantages:
- Les graphismes: plutôt sympas, et je pense, vraiment bien foutus pour la VR. Une véritable immersion graphique.
- La bande son : Vraiment cool et tout autant immersive.
- L'histoire : on rentre vraiment dedans, le sujet est intéressant. Systeme de choix moraux "importants" (j'insiste sur les guillemets) pas mal, dans l'idée.
- Niveau Gameplay : Ok... 

Inconvénients :
- Durée de jeu : bon soyons clairs, le jeu se finit facilement en 3h00 max. Et encore, en prenant vraiment le temps de tout bien explorer comme il faut, en prenant une douche et en mangeant sa pizz' sur l'écran pause pendant la moitié du temps imparti...
- L'histoire : j'avais trouvé l'histoire vraiment accrochante au début, mais comment peut-on creuser ce genre de sujet en si peu de temps? Là franchement, ils ne sont pas allés jusqu'au bout c'est clair. Et même sans cela, au début on est largué dans un univers, plutôt noyés par les informations, chose qui ne s'accorde pas quand l'histoire se dénoue en si peu de temps.
- Les "Enigmes" et "Puzzles" : si vous êtes fans des jeux d'énigmes franchement sur celui-là vous ne risquez pas de vous cassez les dents... d'une simplicité décevante. 
- Les Choix : pour moi un choix est fait pour être sanctionné d'une conséquence... Mais pas dans The Assembly! Ne pensez pas qu'on se retrouve dans les locaux d'une organisation en pouvant sauver ou tuer des tas de gens juste à cause de nos choix! Ben non! Non... Simplement non, non pas ici...
- Et forcément quand on a autant d'inconvénients le derniers et pas des moindres reste le PRIX: 19,99e! 

Résumé: 
A tester si vous en avez l'occasion, en VR, en ayant conscience de sa petite durée de jeu. Mais ne faîtes pas comme moi, attendez qu'il soit soldé ou que quelqu'un vous l'offre :D!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003292839', 'num_games_owned': 1429, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1469045460}
review:
Oh, The Assembly...

Well, for a "walking simulator" it's quite serviceable.
As is usually the case in these games, you spend most
of the time walking around, inspecting different items while looking
for the handful of specific ones that will let you move on to the
next area. It's par for the course and works like you'd expect.
The game also has some simple but neat puzzle solving sprinkled in
to break up the monotony, which is a welcome distraction when it occurs.

Presentation isn't bad, with clean graphics and some "hit or miss" voice acting.
The story is interesting enough, relatively speaking, if somewhat slow.
It's nowhere near as profound as it presents itself as, but - given what else is out
on the VR platforms right now, it could have been a lot worse and still came out
better than most of it's competitors.

As a VR game on the whole, however, it's not much to celebrate.

For the most part, it uses a crosshair in the middle of your sights to target things,
much like you would choose a scene in Oculus Dreamdeck.
Sadly, there is no way to decouple the HMD movement from your virtual body,
so moving around never feels natural.
There is also no support for VIVE motion controllers, even though the simple 3-button control
scheme could easily have been mapped to one of the wands.
The developer cites "VR parity" as the reason for this, and have said that they will not be
implementing support for those controllers.

Which brings me to the elephant in the room, of course.
nDreams have received plenty of feedback (most of it bad) regarding
their pricing model on the Steam forums - and while the company servbot, JennyB,
keeps rehashing a canned response (when she should have been apologizing instead)
about how the higher priced VR bundle is actually the base game,
that doesn't change the fact that we are charged a de facto premium
compared to playing the game in 2D.
This looks especially poor given the engine the game is built on,
and how the bare-bones VR implementation suggests that they've
simply just unticked the "VR checkbox" in Unreal4.

So, you know. The day a publisher makes a game's "ultra" graphics settings a paid DLC (since that's
something not everyone will be able to enjoy) you'll know who to thank for setting that precedent.

More detail can be found in the developer's official reply here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/373650/discussions/0/359543951713952090/#c359543951714277675

review:
The Assembly ist eine gut verpackte Geschichte um ein Labor im Nirgendwo und handelt von einem Doktor, der bereits für The Assembly arbeitet, aber diverse Machenschaften aufdeckt und einer Ärztin, die in der Vergangenheit wegen "unmoralischen" Experimenten ihren Beruf aufgeben musste und nun den Einstellungstest für The Assembly absolviert.
Durch diese Teilung der Geschichte lernt man die beiden Aspekte der geheim agierenden Organisation kennen.
Das krude innere und das freundliche "äußere", wenn neue Leute eingestellt werden sollen.

Insgesamt bietet The Assembly einige gute Rätsel. Diese sind nicht zu schwer zu lösen, machen aber Spass.
Die Bewegungssteuerrung ist etwas gewöhnungsbedürftig, da man mit dem X-Box Controller entweder läuft (ruckartig in sehr kleinen Schritten) oder sich portieren kann (meist die bessere Wahl). Beim portieren sieht man den eigenen Charakter wo und wie er stehen wird, allerdings steht man trotzdem immer nur in der aktuellen Blickrichtung. Das ist etwas Schade, dass man sich hier nicht entsprechend der "Holo-Figur" auch gleich aufstellt.

Das Spiel löst Motion Sickness meiner Meinung nach vollkommen durch die Arten der Fortbewegung, auch wenn dies noch nicht ideal funktioniert.

Fazit:
Das Spiel kann ich uneingeschränkt allen empfehlen, die eine Popcorn-Kino-Story und ein paar Rätsel mögen. Die Umsetzung ist insgesamt super, die Geschichte wird gut erzählt und man fühlt sich in den Episoden der Personen gut herein versetzt.
Einzig die Spielzeit von knapp 2 Stunden ist leider etwas kurz geraten.

review: VR Review: Als erstes möchte ich mich bei den Entwicklern für die verschiedenen Fortbewegungsoptionen bedanken (ich bevorzuge die "normale" yaw-bewegung mit dem controller). Es ist natürlich schade, das das Spiel weder die Vive Controller noch roomscale unterstützt aber Spaß gemacht hat es mir bisher trotzdem. Das Spiel ist jedoch sicherlich kein Meisterwerk. Einige einfache aber auch nicht so leicht durchschaubare Puzzles sind zu lösen und man verbringt viel Zeit damit Schubladen und Schränke zu öffnen. Alledings macht es auch sehr viel Laune in VR durch die schöne Spiellandschaft zu laufen, ein paar Aufgaben zu lösen und der Geschichte zu folgen und dabei einfach nur ein bisschen zu relaxen. Wer Action erwartet ist hier fehl am Platz und ich bin dankbar für mal wieder eine andere Erfahrung als den xten wave shooter zu zocken (jo die machen auch Spass). Das Spiel lief bei mir bisher absolut flüssig und ohne Probleme (i5 6600k, Gtx 980ti, 16gb ddr4). VR Wertung: 6/10. Ich bin gespannt was das Studio für die Zukunft plant. Story und auf Erkundung basierende Spiele sind einfach toll in der virtuellen Realität. A Chair In A Room bleibt hier aber weiterhin ungeschlagen (gefolgt von The Gallery und dem Solus Project).

author: {'steamid': '76561197980798115', 'num_games_owned': 771, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1470368432}
review:
Highly recommended, the Assembly is one of the few VR games that feels like a complete experience. 
-Adventure game where you take the role of 2 people who are having very different experiences.
One is a new comer who is going through a series of trials (read puzzles)  The other is an insider with an agenda.
-Excellent graphics, lots of attention to detail which helps immerse you in the setting; A large science facility.
- An interesting story that is presented via, notes recording, emails and conversations. The voice work is well done, all in service of inhabiting the different characters perspectives.
-  Movement system provides a choice between traditional fps controls or a blink\teleport system so that you can play in the fashion you feel most comfortable with. 
-Gameplay follows standard adventure game conventions, interact with objects and clues, and search spaces to find answers. This is mixed with the aforementioned puzzle sections which so far include spatial puzzles known as “trials”
Conclusion:
If you are looking for something a bit deeper that 8th wave shooter clone, the Assembly fits the bill. Right now many of the VR games on the market amount to glorified tech demos and the Assembly is a welcome change of pace. The biggest praise I can give it, is this game would stand on its own without the VR elements, but I’m glad that they are there as they add to experience and really help you to inhabit the view points of the main characters. 
Tech notes:
Seated experience
I played with a Xbox controller, though it looks like keyboard and mouse controls are available too
Had no trouble performance wise, everything seemed smooth, but I didn’t see any graphics options, so played with how ever it was setup.
Specs:
I5 4690k
Sli 980’s
16gb ram
Installed on my mech WD hdd
